{ "step_by_step_thinking": "Pre-eclampsia is a pregnancy complication characterized by high blood pressure and signs of damage to another organ system, often the liver and kidneys. It usually begins after 20 weeks of pregnancy in women whose blood pressure had been normal. In the case of superimposed pre-eclampsia in a pregnant female with chronic hypertension, we would expect to see new onset proteinuria (A), a decrease in platelet count (B), and an increase in blood pressure (C). However, fresh retinal hypertensive changes (D) are not a typical sign of superimposed pre-eclampsia. They are more associated with malignant hypertension, which is a severe form of high blood pressure.", "answer_choice": "D" }
